THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD OF THE CHEVY

dialogues.speaker: EXT. 7-ELEVEN NIGHT
dialogues.text: A beat-up Chevy pulls into the all-night store's empty pa lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to stand up and fly straight,  but it wasn't easy with that sumbitch  Reagan in the White House... Hi is getting out of the Chevy in a Hawaiian shirt, holdi a pump-action shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I dunno, they say he's a decent  man, so... He primes the shotgun - WHOOSH - CLACK - and heads for th store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...maybe his advisers are confused.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH
dialogues.text: Full-face exposure of Hi once again in front of the mug-s wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn to the right! Hi obliges but shoots sympathetic glances at Ed who is  obviously upset, wiping away tears and snuffling behind t camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Ed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My fai-ants left me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said her fiancГ©e had run off  with a student cosmetologist who  knew how to ply her feminine wiles.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH
dialogues.text: On Hi's profile. He turns back to Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sumbitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget his phone call, Ed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell him I think he's a damn  fool, Ed. You tell him I said so -  H.I. McDunnough. And if he wants to  discuss it he knows where to find  me... As another police officer starts to lead him away:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...in the Maricopa County Maximum  Security Correctional Facility for  Men...

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Looking up through her tears as Hi is led away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...State Farm Road Number Thirty- one; Tempe, Arizona...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HI
dialogues.text: Struggling to call back over his shoulder as he is firmly led out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'll be waiting! The door slams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Hi is once again escorted toward his cell. The Mopping Con is now in the middle-background, having w his way about halfway up the corridor since last time we him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't say I was happy to be back  inside, but the flood of familiar  sights, sounds and faces almost made  it feel like a homecoming.

dialogues.speaker: MOPPING CON
dialogues.text: As Hi passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grrrr...

dialogues.speaker: PRISON HALL
dialogues.text: Group is meeting again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most men your age, Hi, are getting  married and raising up a family.  They wouldn't accept prison as a  substitute. Hi looks sheepish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Would any of you men care to  comment? Two convicts sitting next to each other, GALE and EVELLE, appear to be friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But sometimes your career gotta come  before family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work is what's kept us happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but Doc Schwartz is sayin' you  gotta accept responsibilities. I  mean I'm proud to say I got a  family... somewheres.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking down from the ceiling. In the foreground, lying o the top bunk, hands clasped behind his head as he stares into space is MOSES. Moses is a gnarled, elderly black co with wire-rimmed spectacles. On the lower bunk, also with hands clasped behind his head and staring off at the same spot in space, is Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to sort through what the Doc  had said, but prison ain't the easiest  place to think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An' when they was no meat we ate  fowl. An' when they was no fowl we  ate crawdad. An' when they was no  crawdad to be foun', we ate San'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ate what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ate San'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ate sand?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dass right...

dialogues.speaker: PAROLE BOARD ROOM
dialogues.text: Hi faces the same three PAROLE OFFICERS across the same t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well Boy, you done served your twenty  munce, and seeing as you never use  live ammo, we got no choice but to  return you to society.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These doors goan swing wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to hurt anyone, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, we respect that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're just hurtin' yourself  with this rambunctious behavior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of a 7-Eleven parking lot, at night, deserted except for  Hi's car which sits untended, its engine rumbling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I don't know how you come down  on the incarceration question... Hi backpedals into frame with a shotgun and a bag of cash

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...whether it's for rehabilitation  or revenge. He spins and grabs his car-door handle. Locked. He tries back door. Locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But I was beginning to think... As we hear the wail of an approaching siren, Hi takes it the heel and toe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that revenge is the only argument  makes any sense.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH
dialogues.text: On Hi against the mug-shot wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn to the right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget his latents, Ed!

dialogues.speaker: HI'S HAND
dialogues.text: We see his right hand being efficiently manipulated by Ed two hands: She is rolling each of his inked fingers into appropriate space on an exemplar sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear about the paddy-wagon collided  with the segment mixer, Ed? Twelve  hardened criminals escaped. Ed's hand lingers on top of his.  Hi's other hand enters rest on top of hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a new beau?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Hi, I sure don't. Hi slips a ring off his own finger and slides it onto Ed'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I paid for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The surly Mopping Con has now worked his way up to the  foreground. Hi is being escorted past him to his cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say that absence makes the heart  grow fonder, and for once they may  be right. Halfway up the corridor Hi points casually at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You missed a spot. The Mopping Con turns to watch him recede.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grrrr...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same high shot with Moses on the top bunk, Hi on the lowe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More and more my thoughts turned to  Ed, and I finally felt the pain of  imprisonment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An' momma would frow the live crawdad  in a pot of boiln' water. Well one  day I decided to make my own  crawdad... We begin to crane down to tighten on the absently staring Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...an' I frew it in a pot, forgettin'  to put in the water, ya see... Moses' voice is mixing down as we lose him from frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and it was like I was makin'  popcorn, ya see... The joint is a  lonely place after lock-up and fights  out... We are now very close on Hi, staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...when the last of the cons has  been swept away by the sandman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The underside of the top bunk. A sudden flash whitens and fades to leave the image of Ed smiling behind her camera, softly supered on the undersid of the bunk.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HI
dialogues.text: He wearily turns his head to profile on the pillow and sh his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I couldn't help thinking that a  brighter future lay ahead - a future  that was only eight to fourteen months  away. Eyes closed, he is illuminated by a flash.

dialogues.speaker: PAROLE BOARD ROOM
dialogues.text: Hi and the same three officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a name for people like you, Hi.  That name is called recidivism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ree-peat O-fender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a pretty name, is it, Hi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Sir, it sure ain't. That's one  bonehead name. But that ain't me  anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not just tellin' us what we  wanna hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Sir, no way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause we just wanna hear the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then I guess I am tellin' you  what you wanna hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, didn't we just tell you not to  do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over Hi's shoulder as he strides toward a door marked  "Processing" and flings it open. It is the familiar booking room. Ed looks up from her cam having just snapped a picture of another suspect against hatched wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm walkin' in here on my knees, Ed -  a free man proposin'. Hi cocks a finger at the suspect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy Kurt.

dialogues.speaker: ED'S ROOM
dialogues.text: As she nervously frets at her white bridal gown in front a mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget the boo-kay, Ed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gazing earnestly into the camera. A congregation is seate behind her - the bride's side wearing police blues; the  groom's side, Hawaiian shirts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also staring into the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet I do.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: Over their shoulders, the minister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay then.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH
dialogues.text: On the newlyweds smiling at the camera.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH
dialogues.text: On the newlyweds smiling at each other, profile to the ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the middle of a vast expanse of desert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed's pa staked us to a starter home  in suburban Tempe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi is working the drill press, wearing goggles and sweat- stained overalls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and I got a job drilling holes in  sheet metal. Next to him idly stands Bud, a veteran of the shop, with grimy face and a pair of goggles pushed up on his forehea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we was doin' paramedical work in  affiliation with the state highway  system-not actually practicin',  y'understand - and me and Bill's  patrollin' down Nine Mile -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill Roberts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not that motherscratcher! Bill  Parker! Anyway, we're approachin'  the wreck, and there's a spherical  object arestin' on the highway... He pauses to blow and pop a bubble with his chewing gum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And it don't look like a piece a  the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mostways the job was a lot like  prison, except Ed was waitin' at the  end of every day...

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER'S WINDOW
dialogues.text: Hi is scowling at his paycheck. Behind the barred window fat cashier grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and a paycheck at the end of every  week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gummint do take a bite, don't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi sits in a lawn chair in front of the trailer. Ed sits his lap, his arms around her. Both are wearing sunglasses looking at the setting sun. The scene is suffused with a  warm yellow light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These were the happy days, the salad  days as they say... As the sun sets, the light is turning from yellow to ambe Hi and Ed watch, their heads following its slow downward  arc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and Ed felt that having a critter  was the next logical step. It was  all she thought about. The amber is turning to a more neutral dusky light as the sun has set. Hi and Ed continue to stare at the point whe it disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Her point was that there was too  much love and beauty for just the  two of us... The dusk is slipping away into darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and every day we kept a child out  of the world was a day he might later  regret having missed. We are by now holding on pitch black. Crickets chirp. Fro the darkness:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: A CALENDAR
dialogues.text: Ed is crossing off the last day on the calendar before a circled in red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we worked at it on the days we  calculated most likely to be  fruitful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi is wearily entering after a long day at work, clutchin his lunchpail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and we worked at it most other  days just to be sure. Ed flies into frame and leaps into his arms, covering him with kisses.

dialogues.speaker: TRAILER BEDROOM
dialogues.text: In each other's arms, Hi and Ed roll over on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seemed like nothing could stand in  our way now... We pan with them rolling and continue off them to the nig table, on which sits a framed pair of photographs of Hi,  probably taken by Ed: One shows him full face, the other profile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed sits in a lawn chair knitting a booty. Hi stands in Be shorts and an unbuttoned Hawaiian shirt, hosing down the  minuscule patch of front lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...My lawless years were behind me;  our child rearin' years lay ahead.

dialogues.speaker: DUSTY ROAD LEADING UP TO TRAILER DAY
dialogues.text: A squad car, its siren wailing, kicks up dust as it roars into the foreground.

dialogues.speaker: ADOPTION OFFICE
dialogues.text: Hi and Ed are seated on folding chairs facing an agent's  desk. Hi wears a sport coat over his Hawaiian shirt. Ed i in her dress blues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true I've had a checkered past,  but Ed here is an officer of the law  twice decorated...

dialogues.speaker: THE AGENT
dialogues.text: Looking, with a dead pan, from the file to Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...So we figure it kind of evens  out. His face still deadly neutral, the agent looks back down the file and unfolds the accordioned rap sheet, revealing to be a couple feet long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But biology and the prejudices of  others conspired to keep us childless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Ed as she stares vacantly out the passenger window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our love for each other was stronger  than ever...

dialogues.speaker: ON HI
dialogues.text: Driving. He looks from Ed out to the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but I preminisced no return of  the salad days.

dialogues.speaker: TRAILER BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Over Hi's shoulder as he stares listlessly at himself in mirror, a razor held forgotten in one hand, his face half lathered and half shaved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pizazz had gone out of our lives.

dialogues.speaker: TRAILER BEDROOM
dialogues.text: The bedroom is somewhat messy. Ed sits on the edge of the bed, also staring listlessly. Her police uniform is on bu not yet buttoned. Her hands lie palm-up in her lap, like dead fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed lost all interest in both criminal  justice and housekeeping. Soon after,  she tendered her badge.

dialogues.speaker: MACHINE SHOP
dialogues.text: Once again Hi works as his sweaty gum-chewing colleague s idly by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even my job seemed as dry and bitter  as a hot prairie wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So here comes Bill a-walkin' down  Nine Mile - that's Bill Parker,  y'understand - got his sandwich in  one hand, the fuckin' head in the  other...

dialogues.speaker: ON HI DRIVING
dialogues.text: Alone in his Chevy. He looks to the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I even caught myself drivin' by  convenience stores...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7-Eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that weren't on the way home.

dialogues.speaker: TRAILER LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Hi and Ed sit listlessly watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then one day the biggest news hit  the state since they built the Hoover  Dam... Ed perks up, reacting to something on TV. Hi notices her  reaction and also sloughs off his stupor to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The Arizona quints was born.

dialogues.speaker: THE TV
dialogues.text: A newscaster silently reading copy. Behind him news foota of five nurses holding infants mortices in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By "Arizona" quints I mean they was  born to a woman named Florence  Arizona.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HI AND ED
dialogues.text: Watching intently. Eyes still locked on the set, Ed reach her hand out to Hi. Eyes still locked on the set, Hi take her hand in his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you probably guessed, Florence  Arizona is the wife of Nathan Arizona.  And Nathan Arizona - well hell, you  know who he is...

dialogues.speaker: THE TV A LATE-NIGHT LOCAL COMMERCIAL
dialogues.text: NATHAN ARIZONA, a stocky middle-aged man in a white polye suit, is gesturing expansively with his white cowboy hat  toward a one-story warehouse store with a football stadiu parking lot, chroma-keyed in behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mixing up on the TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So come on down to Unpainted Arizona  for the finest selection in fixtures  and appointments for your bathroom,  bedroom, beaudoir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The owner of the largest chain of  unpainted furniture and bathroom  fixture outlets throughout the  Southwest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you can find lower prices  anywhere my name ain't Nathan Arizona!

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HI AND ED
dialogues.text: As they slowly look from the TV set toward each other.

dialogues.speaker: LINE OF NEWSPAPER VENDING MACHINES
dialogues.text: Hi lounges near one of the vending machines as a business puts in a quarter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep, Florence had been taking  fertility pills, and she and Nathan  had hit the jackpot. The businessman takes his newspaper and releases the mach door as he turns to leave. Hi snags the door before it closes and takes his own five finger discount copy. He flips the paper over to look at the headline.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT PAGE OF NEWSPAPER
dialogues.text: The banner headline of the Tempe Intelligencer is:

dialogues.speaker: "ARIZONA QUINTS GO HOME
dialogues.text: The subhead: "More Than We Can Handle,' Laughs Dad." Next it is a picture of Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now y'all who're without sin can  cast the first stone... A pull back from the paper shows Hi and Ed reading it tog at home. They look from the paper to each other. Hi opens to an inside page and we pan a row of pictures - the five tots with their names underneath: "HARRY, BARRY, LARRY, GARRY and NATHAN JR."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but we thought it was unfair that  some should have so many while others  should have so few.

dialogues.speaker: BILLBOARD
dialogues.text: In the middle of the desert. It reads: "WELCOME TO TEMPE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are floating in toward Ed who is seated, waiting, in t driver's seat of Hi's Chevy. Hi enters frame and cinches  down a ladder that is tied to the roof of the car. Pieces red flag flutter at either end of the ladder where it sti out beyond the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the benefit of hindsight maybe  it wasn't such a hot idea... Hi gets in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It starts down the long, winding road leading away from t trailer, kicking up dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but at the time, Ed's little plan  seemed like the solution to all our  problems, and the answer to all our  prayers. The title of the film burns in: "RAISING ARIZONA". A buil chord snaps off in a shock cut to:

dialogues.speaker: SUBURBAN LIVING ROOM EVENING
dialogues.text: Tableau of a couple at home. Nathan Arizona is on the  telephone, his stocking feet up on an ottoman. Florence s reading Dr. Spock's Baby and Child Care. The living room is dominated by a large oil portrait of N and Florence, gazing out from the wall over the mantelpie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight hundred leaf tables and no  chairs?! You can't sell leaf tables  and no chairs! Chairs, you got a  dinette set! No chairs, you got dick!  I ask my wife she got more sense!...

dialogues.speaker: "THE ARIZONA HOUSEHOLD"
dialogues.text: From somewhere upstairs we hear an infant start to cry.  Florence stops reading and looks up at the ceiling. Natha is oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Miles, all I know is I'm away  from the office to have me some kids  and everything goes straight to heck!  I ain't gonna stand for it! Another title is supered below the first: "SEPTEMBER 17,  1985". The baby stops crying and Florence's attention ret to her book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yeah, and if a frog had wings he  wouldn't bump his ass a-hoppin'! I'm  sick of your excuses, Miles! It is  now... As he throws out his wrist to look at his watch a third t is supered beneath the first two: 8:45 p.m.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...8:45 in the p.m. I'm gonna be  down to the store in exactly twelve  hours to kick me some butt! He starts to replace the receiver but brings it back with afterthought:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Or my name ain't Nathan Arizona! As he slams the phone into the cradle the titles disappea Another baby starts crying. Florence looks up at the ceil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds like Larry. Close on the crying baby as Hi bounces it, gently but  desperately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhh! Shh! Nice baby... He starts to lower it back into the crib. The crib is  unpainted with the name of each baby burned Bonanza-style into the headboard: Harry, Barry, Larry, Garry, and Natha Jr. Instead of quieting as he is lowered into the crib, t squalling baby only sets off one of his brothers. Hi hurr lifts him back out. He looks desperately around the room. The room is wallpapered with nursery rhyme characters. There are toys strewn around. There is one adult-sized ea chair in the corner. Hi carries the baby over to the chair, stepping on and  reacting to the squeal of a squeeze-me toy on the way. He sits the baby deep in - the chair and then returns to the crib to deal with the second crying baby. He lifts the baby out of the crib and gently bounces it.  This baby stops crying. Another one in the crib starts bawling. Hi sets the second baby down on the floor and gives it a  rattle to keep it pacified. He reaches for the third baby the crib. Sweat stands out on Hi 's brow. He is desperate chucking the third baby under the chin when we hear a muf

dialogues.speaker: PTHUMP
dialogues.text: He whirls to look across the darkened room. The first baby has dropped off the easy chair and is  energetically crawling away toward a shadowy corner.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Nathan and Florence are sitting stock-still, staring at t ceiling. After a moment, another baby starts crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're they, playing telephone? They stare at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: NURSERY
dialogues.text: Loose babies are crawling everywhere. Hi is skittering ac the room in a half-crouch, a baby tucked under one arm,  reaching out with the other as he pursues a crawling baby across the room. He hefts the other baby with his free arm and brings the back to the crib. He turns to look frantically around the room. The other three babies have disappeared. There is perfect quiet. Hi goes over to the closet door, which is ajar, and swing it open. He reaches under a moving pile of clothes on the floor an pulls out a baby. He returns it to the crib and freezes, listening. The sound of a rattle. He drops to the floor to look under the crib.

dialogues.speaker: CRIB
dialogues.text: A baby holding a rattle leers into the camera in the  foreground. Behind him Hi, on his stomach, is reaching in grab at his leg. Hi is pulling the baby out, away from the camera, when wi a plop! a baby drops onto Hi 's back from the crib above. Hi twists one arm back to grope for the baby crawling on of him. He is straightening up, a baby in each arm, when he react in horror to something he sees across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hindquarters of a diapered baby are just disappearing around the corner of the nursery door into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Florence and Nathan are staring at the ceiling. After a b we hear a muffled plop! on the ceiling. A beat later, the bleat of the squeeze-me toy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Whyn't you go up and check on  'em? They sound restless.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS HALLWAY
dialogues.text: The floor-level wide-angle shot shows a baby crawling tow the camera in the foreground. Behind him, in the backgrou just rounding the open door from the nursery, yet another baby is making a mad dash for freedom. Hi emerges from the nursery and, stepping around the  background baby, trots toward the baby in the foreground. the time he reaches it the low-angle cropping shows us on his feet and calves.

dialogues.speaker: HI
dialogues.text: Perspiring as he tiptoes the last two steps to the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baby and, beyond it, the stairway down to the main fl We hear footsteps approaching.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HI
dialogues.text: He scoops up the baby and hurriedly tiptoes away toward t nursery.

dialogues.speaker: LOW-ANGLE REVERSE
dialogues.text: The baby at the nursery door in the foreground; the stair in the background. As Hi reaches the baby we hear footste climbing the stairs. Hi's free arm comes down into frame to scoop the baby up out of frame just as: Florence's head appears, bobbing up as she climbs the sta She approaches the nursery, still clutching the Dr. Spock book.

dialogues.speaker: NURSERY
dialogues.text: As Florence enters from the hallway door. We track back into the room, on her, as she approaches th crib. Halfway there she freezes, staring, in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of the babies have been replaced in the crib but not  lying down: They are seated in a row, staring back at her lined up against the far crib railing, like a small but  distinguished panel on "Meet the Press."

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD OF THE CHEVY
dialogues.text: ED'S POV of Hi approaching the car. He is shrugging and  displaying a pair of manifestly empty hands.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Barely able to fight down her anger. Hissing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?! Hi appears at her - the driver's-window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry honey, it just didn't work  out. He is reaching to open the door but she slaps his hand aw from the handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you mean it didn't work out?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They started cryin', then they were  all over me... He is trying to open the door, which Ed is holding shut w all her might.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It was kinda horrifying - Lemme  in, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course they cried! Babies cry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that now! Come on honey, we  better leave - Ed is rolling up the window and locking the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go right back up there and get  me a toddler! I need a baby, Hi;  they got more'n they can handle! Muffled, through the closed window, and very forlorn:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw honey I -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you come back here without a  baby!

dialogues.speaker: NURSERY
dialogues.text: Florence is holding one of the babies cradled against her shoulder. She is facing the hallway door; her back is to crib and window. The baby, peeping out over her shoulder, facing the window.

dialogues.speaker: BABY
dialogues.text: Looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the window, as Hi's head appears in it.

dialogues.speaker: BABY
dialogues.text: Looking.

dialogues.speaker: HI
dialogues.text: Looking back, he holds a finger to his lips.

dialogues.speaker: BABY
dialogues.text: Florence starts bouncing it, patting it on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi and the window bouncing up and down.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Nathan is leafing through the lingerie ads in the newspap We can hear Florence's returning footsteps. Muttering:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian Dior my butt... Florence enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...They pay money for that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're the kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' kids, I love 'em. We hear the bleat of the squeeze-me toy. Florence and Nat look at the ceiling for a beat, then Nathan clears his th and returns to the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: CHEVY
dialogues.text: Ed sits anxiously waiting in the driver's seat, peering  intently through the windshield. As she catches sight of  something she breaks into a broad smile, unlocks the door and slides over to the passenger seat. Hi is opening the door with one hand, cradling a baby in other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one ya get? As he gets into the driver's seat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. Nathan Jr., I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme here. He hands her the infant, then hands her the copy of Dr.Sp Baby and Child Care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he's beautiful! Hi nods as he pulls away from the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's awful damn good. I think I got  the best one. Ed is gushing and kissing the baby through the rest of th conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet they were all beautiful. All  babies are beautiful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. This one's awful damn good  though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you cuss around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's fine, he is. I think it's Nathan  Jr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are doin' the right thing, aren't  we Hi? - I mean, they had more'n  they could handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now honey we been over this and  over this. There's what's right and  there's what's right, and never the  twain shall meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't think his momma'll be  upset? I mean overly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well a course she'll be upset, sugar,  but she'll get over it. She's got  four little babies almost as good as  this one. It's like when I was robbin'  convenience stores - Ed suddenly bursts out crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love him so much!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you do, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still sobbing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love him so much!

dialogues.speaker: TRAILER LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: As the lights are thrown on. The room is hung with stream A string of cut-out letters reads "Welcome Home Son!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, bring him in!

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: Ed is entering with Nathan Jr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it young Nathan Jr. Just  feast your eyes about, old boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be so loud around him, Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, I'm sorry honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't you cuss around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, he don't know a cuss word from  shinola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well see that he don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jovially)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's all right, he is. He reaches for the child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Come on over here, Nathan Jr.,  I'll show you around. He takes the baby in both hands and holds him out at arm' length, pointing him at the various places of interest. T baby looks goggle-eyed at each one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Lookahere, young sportsman. That -  there's the kitchen area where Ma  and Pa chow down. Over there's the  TV, two hours a day maximum, either  educational or football so's you  don't ruin your appreciation of the  finer things. This - here's the divan,  for sociahzin' and relaxin' with the  family unit. Yessir, many's the day  we sat there and said wouldn't it be  nice to have a youngster here to  share our thoughts and feelin's - Impatient with the nonsense:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's tired, Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we'll just sit you right there,  boy... He is propping Nathan Jr. up in the corner of the couch. sits at the other corner and Ed sits in a facing chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Just put those dogs up'n take a  load off. Hi beams at Nathan Jr. Ed smiles at Nathan Jr. Nathan Jr. looks from one to the other, deadpan. They seem to be wai for him to contribute to the conversation. Silence. Suddenly Hi slaps his knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you kiddin'?! We got a family  here! Ed is getting up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He's a scandal, honey! He's a  little outlaw! As she picks up the baby:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a good boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't too good! You can tell by  that twinkle in his eye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think we should put him to  bed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on, honey... He is frantically reaching for a Polaroid camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Let's us preserve the moment in  pictures!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one, okay?... She sits down on the couch with Nathan Jr. as Hi starts  screwing the camera into a tripod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I gotta tell ya, I'm a little  scared. Absently, as he sets up the camera:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come is that, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we got a baby, Hi. It's an awful  big responsibility. As he peers through the lens:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, could ya slide over a tad and  raise the nipper up? As she complies:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean we never done this before and  I'm kinda nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doin' real good, sugar. Hi sits on the couch, holding the camera's cable release. puts his arm around Ed and smiles at the offscreen camera Ed nestles her head against Hi's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're set to pop here, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna help, aren't ya? Through his teeth as he continues to grin at the offscree camera:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give Nathan Jr. a normal family  background, just quiet evenings at  home together... We begin to hear distant thunder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can count on it, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Everything decent'n normal from  here on out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. As he squeezes the cable release - FLASH - the image  momentarily freezes on Hi beaming, Nathan Jr. staring, an Ed looking at Hi with a little bit of concern.

dialogues.speaker: DARK FIELD SAME NIGHT
dialogues.text: The rolling thunder has built to a thunderclap at the cut and the flash of the Polaroid match cuts to lightning thr a momentarily harsh glare on the field. Rain beats down on the bare patch of ground we are lookin at - by now just a patch of mud. Faraway lightning flickers and we hear the rumble of more thunder approaching, then suddenly: THWACK - A head pops up out of the mud. It is Gale, the c we saw in group therapy. He bellows as lightning and thun flash and crack nearby. His head is covered with mud, although the driving rain i already starting to wash it away. We are beginning to track in an arc around Gale's head, w is now struggling, working to get his shoulders and arms out of the mud. The end of the 180-degree arc and a flash lightning reveal, way in the distance, the wire-topped wa of a penitentiary. Still bellowing, as if in some primal rage, Gale has gott his muck-covered arms up out of the earth and is now push down to haul up the rest of his body. It comes with much  effort, and with the loud sucking-popping sounds of the  fiercely clinging mud. Finally he is free. With a great cry, the mud-covered man plunges his right a straight back down into the earth, all the way up to his  shoulder. He gropes intently and then, apparently having  grabbed hold of something underground, he starts pulling. His arm comes slowly back up out of the mud. Clasped in h hand is - a human foot. Bellowing with effort he continues to pull, liberating th foot... leg... torso of his companion, and finally his he As the rain starts to wash the mud off his companion's he we see that it is his friend Evelle. Both are bellowing. Mud sucks and pops. Thunder crashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the cut the ear-splitting thunder drops out to quiet. hear only the muffled patter of rain and the hum of a bar fluorescent. The two bedraggled escaped cons are standing side by side combing their hair in the mirror. The men seem absorbed i their task, using hair jelly from a jar that sits on the  shelf between them to restore their duck's-ass haircuts. Evelle cracks the bathroom door and looks out into the ra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercury. Looks nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men are trotting out to a Mercury that sits unten at a gas island, a gas hose on automatic stuck in its tan As Gale starts up the car Evelle yanks the hose out and d it to the ground. Gale is already starting to peel out as Evelle gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late at night. Hi sits asleep on the sofa at the far end the room, in a pool of lamp light. We hear faint, distant knocking. As we track in toward Hi the knocking becomes louder and more present. As we approach Hi we see that several Polaroids are sprea over his gently rising and falling chest. By the time we tighten on his face the knocking has becom quite loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open up! Hi starts awake with a grunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Open up in air! He looks up, alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door of the trailer. Someone is pounding  insistently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open up! It's a police!

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HI
dialogues.text: He sits up and tenses. He looks around. Ed stands in her nightgown at the mouth of the hallway,  holding Nathan Jr. and squinting at Hi. She hisses:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi! What's goin' on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Po-lice, son! Open her up! Hi gets to his feet, hurriedly tosses the Polaroids under cushion of the couch and takes out a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ain't gonna take Nathan?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'd like to see 'em fly. As Ed turns back to the bedroom:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open up and maybe we'll letcha plea- bargain.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: As Ed enters and shuts the door. She listens hard at the  door: Hi's footsteps cross the living room, the click of the do opening, silence... a burst of raucous male laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Honey! Come on out here! Want you  to meet a couple friends of mine!

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: As Ed enters, carrying Nathan Jr. All three men - Hi, Gal and Evelle - are beaming at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, like you to meet Gale and  Evelle Snopes, fine a pair as ever  broke and entered. Gale roars with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Boys, this - here's my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miz McDunnough. Ed smiles politely, then squints at Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of late for visitors, isn't it  Hi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well yeah honey, but these boys tell  me they just got outta the joint.  Gotta show a little hospitality. Gale is admiring the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now H.I., looks like you been  up to the devil's bidnis!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That a him or a her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a little boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a name, does he? Hi and Ed look at each other uncomfortably. Hi clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well so far we just been using Junior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We call him Junior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, thairs good - JR., just like on  the Teevee. Gale is staring at the streamers and decorations. Reading aloud:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Welcome... Home... Son." Where's he  been? Hi and Ed respond simultaneously:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tulsa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phoenix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was, uh... he was visiting his  grandparents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're separated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that yer folks ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought yer folks was dead, H.I.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very uncomfortably)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we thought Junior should see  their final resting place - Whyn't  you boys have a seat? As the two men move toward the couch Ed hesitantly pipes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, it's two in the morning... She wrinkles her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What's that smell? Apologetically:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't always smell like this, Miz  McDunnough. I was just explainin' to  yer better half here that when we  were tunneln' out we hit the main  sewer - dumb luck, that - and just  followed that to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you busted out of jail!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waaaal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We released ourselves on our own  recognizance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Evelle means to say is, we felt  the institution no longer had anything  to offer us. He is looking at the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...My Lord he's cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a little outlaw, you can see  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen, you folks can't stay  here! Gale, Evelle, and Hi look up at Ed, dumbstruck. After a b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just can't stay! I appreciate  your bein' friends of Hi and all,  but this is a decent family now... She looks at Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I mean we got a toddler here! Gale leans in close to Hi, a look of sincere concern on h face, and says under his breath:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, who wears the pants round here

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now honey -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you honey me. Now you boys can  set a while and catch up, and then  you'll be on your way. There is an awkward silence as she leaves and slams the  bedroom door. Gale is carefully studying his thumbnail; Evelle stares  fixedly at the ceiling. Still looking at his thumb:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotcha on a awful short leash, don't  she H.I.?

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Sometime later, as Hi tiptoes in. Ed lies in bed facing t wall; we see only the back of her head. Hi sits gingerly the edge of the bed and, smiling, sticks a finger through the bars of the crib to play with the baby. The sound of the TV set in the living room filters faintl in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They still here? Hi is momentarily startled, then goes on playing with the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, they're just gonna stay a day  or two. It's raining out honey, they  got nowhere to go. Ed finally turns to face him. We hear the two men laugh  raucously in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're fugitives, Hi... Hi turns to face her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...How're we gonna start a new life  with them around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now honey you gotta have a little  charity. Ya know, in Arab lands they'd  set out a plate -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise just a day or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight and tomorrow, tops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking straight down at Hi, asleep in bed. It is later:  filtering softly in from the other room is the end of the "Star Spangled Banner" on TV. We are craning down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That night I had a dream.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH CUT
dialogues.text: For a brief moment we see a wall of flames and hear it ro

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HI
dialogues.text: Still craning down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'd drifted off thinkin' about  happiness, birth, and new life...

dialogues.speaker: FLASH CUT
dialogues.text: Wall of flames. Deafening roar.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HI
dialogues.text: Craning down. The faint National Anthem ends: we hear the WEEEEEEEE of a test pattern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now I was haunted by a vision of -

dialogues.speaker: WALL OF FLAMES
dialogues.text: Roaring. At the cut: WHOOOOOSH! a huge low-rider motorcyc bursts through the flames, its engine roaring even louder than the fire. Its driver is a huge leather-clad hellion. The chains worn by the Biker clank ominously as he rides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was horrible... The Biker roars out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: LOW-ANGLE REVERSE
dialogues.text: As the Biker roars into frame, his rear tire laying down wake of fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a lone biker of the apocalypse...

dialogues.speaker: BIKER
dialogues.text: As he roars along a ribbon of desert highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a man with all the powers of her  at his command. The Biker reaches for his bullwhip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He could turn the day into night... The Biker cracks the whip and, at the crack: The sky behind him turns instantly to black. Bolts of  lightning crackle across it as thunder roars.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER DESERT SCENE DAY
dialogues.text: Tracking with and also in on the Biker from behind as he  roars along a strip of highway. He is reaching for the tw sawed-off shotguns which are strapped crisscross across h back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and laid to waste everything in  his path.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE TRACK ON BIKER
dialogues.text: Pulling the Biker from a distance as he levels the two  shotguns. The tracking camera pulls back further to revea running jack-rabbit keeping pace with us in the foregroun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was especially hard on the little  things... CRACK - as the first shotgun spurts orange the foreground rabbit keels over. The Biker slues the other gun around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a rock in the foreground, a desert lizard suns himself The Biker is approaching in the distant background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the helpless and the gentle  creatures. CRACK - from afar, the foreground lizard is blown away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the empty desert road stretching away. In the foregrou a lone desert flower blooms. The Biker roars into frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He left a scorched earth in his wake,  befouling even the sweet desert breeze  that whipped across his brow. As the Biker roars away, the foreground flower bends with his draft and then bursts into flame.

dialogues.speaker: BIKER
dialogues.text: From in front. He twirls the shotguns in either hand and  reaches back to plunge them over his shoulders into their holsters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know where he came from or  why... We are moving in on his chest, where two crisscrossed  bandoliers carry two rows of hand grenades, their silver  pins glinting in the sun. We follow the line of one of th bandoliers up to his right shoulder which bears the tatto "Mama Didn't Love Me."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know if he was dream or  vision...

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE TRACK ON BIKER
dialogues.text: From behind, booming down as we track. We are approaching the crest of a rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I feared that I myself had  unleashed him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the Biker approaching, craning down as he draws near.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...for he was The Fury That Would  Be... With the crane down we momentarily lose him from view ove the rise; then suddenly - ROAR - he tops the rise and, wh spinning, is airborne

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: As he crashes back down to earth in the foreground and ro away. Only now we are no longer in the desert: We are looking down a twilight street at the end of which the Arizona house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as soon as Florence Arizona found  her little Nathan gone. The roar of his engine and clank of his chains recede as Biker gradually dissolves into thin air. We are left looking at the empty street and the faraway  Arizona house. The receding roar has left behind eerily beautiful singin a woman singing a lullaby. Faintly, behind the singing, t is also a droning high-pitched noise. The camera starts floating forward very close to the grou moving slowly toward the Arizona house. The high-pitched  drone is becoming less faint under the singing. The camera is accelerating. The drone is growing louder - can now tell that it is a human scream. As we approach the Arizona house we can see that a ladder propped up to a second-story window. We are moving quite fast now. The scream all but buries t singing. We are rushing toward the house, toward the base of the  ladder, the sustained scream drawing us on. We hurtle toward and then straight up the ladder with no  abatement of speed, sucked forward by the deafening screa We reach the top and hurtle - THWAP! - through the white  curtains of the open second-story window into the nursery reveal Florence Arizona, her back to us, screaming over t crib. We are rocketing toward her. She is turning to us, hands pressed to her ears, mouth  stretched wide in an ear-splitting shriek and we are rush into an extreme close-up of her gaping mouth and her wild vibrating epiglottis and we

dialogues.speaker: HI'S EYES
dialogues.text: As they snap open. The screaming snaps off at the cut. The singing that the  building scream covered, however, is now audible again. Perspiration beads Hi's forehead. He looks down toward th foot of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: It is now morning. Ed walks back and forth, gently bounci the baby as she walks. She is singing it a lullaby. Faintly, from the next room, we can hear Gale and Evelle  snoring away like buzz saws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (groggily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's all right. He was just havin' a  nightmare. Hi is getting out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... He crosses to the bedroom window and cracks the venetian  blind. Orange light filters in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond a clothes line and a septic tank, a huge orange ba of sun is rising. We can almost hear the roar of its burn surface.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HI
dialogues.text: Looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Sometimes it's a hard world for  little things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orange sun, rumbling, perceptibly rising.

dialogues.speaker: ARIZONA HOME FRONT FOYER
dialogues.text: At the cut the rumble of the sun is snapped off by the hi pitched ba-WEEEEeeee... of a strobe going off as a flash  picture is taken: We are looking over Nathan Jr.'s should as he stands at his open front door, facing a battery of  press people who stand out on the porch. An obie light over a local TV news camera glares in at us various flashbulbs pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the missus and the rest of the  kids've left town to I ain't sayin'  where. They'll be back here when  we're a nuclear fam'ly again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Arizona, which tot was abducted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan Jr., I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have anything to say to the  kidnappers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah: Watch yer butt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, it's been rumored that your son  was abducted by UFOS. Would you care  to comment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't print that, son. If his  mama reads that she's just gonna  lose all hope. A POLICEMAN from inside the house is taking Nathan by the elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We really have to ask you some more  questions, sir... As Nathan allows himself to be led back into the house he calls back over his shoulder:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But remember, it's still business as  usual at Unpainted Arizona, and if  you can find lower prices anywhere  my name still ain't Nathan Arizona! We are following the two, hand-held, as the Police leads  Nathan toward the living room.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: The room is filled with policemen milling about in severa different uniforms: local police, state troopers, plaincl detectives. The original Policeman is leading Nathan to a table where white-smocked technician is preparing inkpad and exemplar sheets. The dialogue is urgent, rapid-fire and overlapping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Byrum here can take your exemplars  while you talk. MR. BYRUM has taken Nathan's right hand and is rolling it fingers onto the inkpad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just let your hand relax; I'll do  the work. Nathan jerks his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?! I didn't steal the  damn kid! Two men in conservative suits are approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, these men are from the FBI-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you boys crazy?! All I know is I  wake up this morning with my wife  screaming-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just need to distinguish your  prints from the perpetrators', if  they left any. Giving his hand back:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Course! I know that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, we have an indication you were  born Nathan Huffhines; is this  correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I changed m'name; what of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you give us an indication why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, would you buy furniture at a  store called Unpainted Huffhines?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll get to the point-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was the child wearing anything when  he was abducted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one sleeps nekkid in this house,  boy! He was wear-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm asking the questions here,  officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we're gonna put out an APB we  need a description of the -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was wearin' his-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that we're better trained  to intervene in crisis situations (to Nathan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was he wearing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dinner jacket! Wuddya think, he  was wearing his damn jammies!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to cop)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The child was wearing his jammies.  Are you happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any disgruntled employees?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, they're all disgruntled! I  ain't runnin' a damn daisy farm!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did the pajamas-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My motto is do it my way or watch  your butt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did the pajamas-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you think it might have been an  employee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make me laugh. Without my say-  so they don't piss with their pants  on fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did the pajamas look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pained)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bellowing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno, they were jammies! They had  Yodas'n shit on 'em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would ya mind, I'm trying to set up  a Command Post here! Nathan bellows back:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your feet off m'damn coffee table! Also raising his voice at the offscreen bellower:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron, you're upsetting the victim. Nathan is getting worked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damnit, are you boys gonna go chase  down your leads or are you gonna sit  drinkin' coffee in the one house in  the state where I know my boy ain't  at?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, there aren't any "leads" yet,  aside from this coat-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme that! He grabs the overcoat being displayed by FBI #2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a five-hundred-dollar camel's  hair-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, you might want to wash your  hands at this point. Nathan realizes that he's gotten ink from his fingerprint all over the coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well goddamnit! He is rising to his feet and hurling the coat to the floo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...No leads?! He furiously kicks the coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Everyone leaves microbes'n whatnot! Throughout the speech Nathan stalks the room, working him into a frenzy, furiously putting coffee cups onto coaster generally cleaning up, hectoring the police, and swiping  their feet off his furniture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hell, that's your forte, trackin'  down them microbes left by criminals'n  commies'n shit! That's yer whole  damn raison d'itre! No leads?! I  want Nathan Jr. back, or whichever  the hell one they took! He's out  there somewhere! Somethin' leads to  him! And anyone can find him knows  the difference between a lead and a  hole in the ground!!

dialogues.speaker: HOLE IN THE GROUND
dialogues.text: Specifically, it is the hole in the muddy patch of earth  that Gale and Evelle climbed out of. We hear only the squ suck of many feet walking around in the mud offscreen. We are pulling back to reveal the feet-the shiny black pa leather shoes and blue pants cuffs - becoming quickly  spattered - of several policemen milling about the hole. German shepherds sniff around also. With a roar, motorcycle wheels enter frame. The bike's  jackbooted rider casually tools around the hole once; pol step back and dogs skitter away to give him room. He backs toward the camera and stops, standing astride th bike. The burning stub of a cheroot is dropped into frame it hisses angrily and dies in the mud. We start to crane The whipcracking Biker cue mixes up. The Biker's motorcyc idles with a deep rumble, like the roar of fire on the su We are now framed looking over the Biker's shoulder. The  policemen's attitude to him seems to be deferential. One in front of him is pointing a direction. The Biker is sha his head; he doesn't think they went that way. Suddenly, with a loud whipcrack effect, the Biker's head  snaps to profile. He is staring across the field, stock-s having heard, smelled or sensed something. The dogs milling around the hole also react, snapping to  attention, a split second after the BIKER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A jackrabbit is bounding away at the far end of the field

dialogues.speaker: THE DOGS
dialogues.text: After a moment, their attention returns to the hole.

dialogues.speaker: THE BIKER
dialogues.text: His attention also returns to the matter at hand. He squi concentrating. His bike rumbles. Gradually his face sets a specific direction. We pan down to the tattoo on his shoulder: "Mama Didn't L Me." His shoulder flexes once or twice as he revs the  throttle; then he puts the bike in gear and it roars out frame.

dialogues.speaker: GALE AND EVELLE
dialogues.text: They are both intently munching cornflakes, staring at  something offscreen. After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Awful good cereal flakes, Miz  McDunnough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed is sitting in the living room, bottle-feeding Nathan J She is surrounded by the rumpled sheets and blankets used the house guests. She does not respond to the ice-breaker Gale puts his spoon down and picks up a cigarette which h been smoking in the ashtray next to him. There is a bead milk dribbling down his chin. He takes a contemplative puff, studying Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Whyncha breast feed him? You 'pear  to be capable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind your own bidnis. Through a mouthful of cornflakes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya don't breast feed him, he'll hate  you for it later. That's why we wound  up in prison. Gale blows out smoke and picks up his spoon to start back on his cornflakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, that's what Doc Schwartz  tells us. Hi is walking in, yawning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morni', H.I. Sharply, as Hi sits and starts to pour cornflakes into a  bowl:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hi. Hi holds the cornflakes box arrested in mid-air. He looks Ed, who is motioning to gale and Evelle with her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah... Say boys, you wouldn't  mind makin' yourself scarce for a  couple hours this afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're havin' some decent friends  over. Gale and Evelle are looking dumbly from Ed to Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heh-heh... What Ed means to say is,  seein' as you two boys are wanted,  it wouldn't exactly do to have folks  seein' you here - I mean for your  own protection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure H.I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything you say. More relaxed now, to Ed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matter of fact honey, maybe I'll  skip this little get-together myself,  Glen won't mind, and I'll just duck  out with the boys, knock back a couple  of-uh, Co-Colas-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure H.I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd love to have ya.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Looking pleadingly at Hi.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HI
dialogues.text: Feeling the look, he goes back to his cornflakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well... maybe that ain't such a  hot idea either. Gale leans back to blow smoke at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So many social engagements. So little  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the bathroom where we earlier saw Gale and Evelle  combing their hair, now empty. We are looking toward the door. The bathroom is quiet exc for the dripping sink, and the faint rumble of an approac motorcycle. It grows louder, then begins to recede as the bike shoots by the station. Suddenly we hear the screech of the bike's brakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are on the road outside the gas station as the motorcy screeches to a halt in the foreground. The low wide shot  crops the BIKER at his shins. In the background behind hi is the gas station. The Biker pauses for a moment, thinking or feeling.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO INT. BATHROOM
dialogues.text: We hear the rumble of the bike approaching, very loud. CRASH - the bathroom door flies open as the Biker bursts astride his hog, bright daylight streaming in with him to throw him into imposing silhouette. The shafts of light  pouring in are defined by motes of dust dancing in the ai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fast track in on the jar of hair jelly sitting on the she under the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BIKER
dialogues.text: An extreme close shot shows his nostrils dilating as we h him sniff. He revs the rumbling bike, stealing thunder from a far  mountain.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT STOOP OF TRAILER
dialogues.text: Hi, with Ed standing by, is just opening the door to a yo couple. Glen is a short stocky blond man in his early  thirties, wearing Bermuda shorts. DOT is wearing slacks,  heels, and a scarf over her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen, Dot- As the door opens, Dot hops up the stoop shrieking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's at baby? Where's he at? From behind, Glen gives her an energetic THWOK on the ass

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go find him honey! Dot spins and smacks Glen across the face with her purse. Through clenched teeth:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it out, Glen! He reels under the blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's asleep right now. Dot shrieks again, but this time muffles it with her own  hand. She tiptoes into the trailer, hand to her mouth. Glen, rubbing his cheek, seems angry at himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, I hope we didn't wake it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I just sneak a peek-a-loo? Glen at the top of the stoop, turns out to the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on kids...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scad of children, ranging in age from two to seven, are crawling over Hi's car. One is beating on it with a large stick, another sits on the hood pulling back one of the  windshield wipers, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Get away from Mr. McDunnough's  car.

dialogues.speaker: TRAILER BEDROOM
dialogues.text: As Ed and Dot enter, Ed beaming as they go to the crib.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... Hi Jr. Till we think of a better  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whyncha call him Jason? I love  Biblical names. If I had another  little boy I'd name him Jason or  Caleb or- Oh! She puts her hand to her forehead, reacting to the baby a if she is about to faint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He's an angel! She hides her face in her hands and looks away as if blin then sneaks a look around her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He's an angel straight from heaven!  Now honey I had all my kids the hard  way so you gotta tell me where you  got this angel. Did he fly straight  down from heaven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna send him to Arizona State?

dialogues.speaker: TRAILER LIVING ROOM / KITCHEN
dialogues.text: The weaving knee-level tracking shot is following a six-y old boy in shorts and a dirty T-shirt as he tramps around the trailer, brandishing a big stick. He strikes the wall furniture, various other objects with his stick, hollerin "Bam! Bam-Bam!" with each blow. The track weaves off him and onto Hi, who is bending down pull a couple of beers from the refrigerator. He raises h voice to make himself heard over the din of all the child boiling around the room:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need a beer, Glen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does the Pope wear a funny hat? Hi considers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well yeah, Glen, I guess it is  kinda funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, that reminds me! How many  Pollacks it take to screw up a  lightbulb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know Glen, one? Hi looks down. One of Glen's children, in a cowboy hat, is squirting a s gun into his crotch area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope, it takes three! He starts laughing, then catches himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Wait a minute, I told it wrong.  Here, I'm startin' over: How come it  takes three Pollacks to screw up a  lightbulb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Glen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause they're so durn stupid! He laughs; Hi doesn't react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Shit man, loosen up! Don't ya get  it? Hi looks over at the TV, which the bam-shouting six-year- is banging with his stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Glen, I sure don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit man, think about it! I guess  it's what they call a Way Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause you only get it on the Way  Home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm already home, Glen. The kid in the cowboy hat is reaching up to slap Hi on th ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wetchaself! Mr. McDunnough wet  hisseff, Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, that reminds me! How'd you get  that kid s'darned fast? Me'n Dottie  went in to adopt on account of  something went wrong with m'semen,  and they told us five years' wait  for a healthy white baby! I said  healthy white baby! Five years! Okay,  what else you got? Said, two Koreans  and one Negro born with the heart  outside... He takes a sip of beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yeah, it's a crazy world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone oughta sell tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I'd buy one. Hi is looking at another child who is just finishing off T in FART in crayon on the wall. Glen chuckles, looking at his errant child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...That Buford's a sly one. Already  knows his ABCs. But I'm sayin', how'd  ya get the kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well this whole thing is just who  knows who and favoritism. Ed has a  friend at one of the agencies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well maybe she can do something for  me'n Dot. See there's something wrong  with m'semen. Say, that reminds me!  What you gonna call him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Ed-Ed Jr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought you said he was a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, as in Edward. Just like that  name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not really interested)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's a good one... Course I  don't really need another kid, but  Dottie says these-here are gettin'  too big to cuddle. Say, that reminds  me! The sound of shattering glass. Glen looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind ya don't cutchaseff, Mordecai...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dot faces Hi and Ed across a picnic table covered with gr hamburgers, rolls, green jello mold, cooler, etc. One of the younger children sits in the middle of the tab occasionally taking a fistful of jello and flinging it at Hi. The two women don't seem to notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and then there's diphtheria- tetanus, what they call dip-tet. You  gotta get him dip-tet boosters yearly  or else he'll get lockjaw and night  vision. Then there's the smallpox  vaccine, chicken pox and measles,  and if your kid's like ours you gotta  take all those shots first to get  him to take 'em. Who's your  pediatrician, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ain't exactly fixed on one yet.  Have we Hi? Hi sits stock-still with a stony face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...No, I guess we don't have one  yet. Dot shrieks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you just gotta have one! You  just gotta have one this instant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, what if the baby gets sick,  honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, even if he don't get sick he's  gotta have his dip-tet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gotta have his dip-tet, honey. Hi shrugs, then flinches as a piece of jello hits his  shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You started his bank accounts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have we done that honey? We gotta do  that honey. What's that for, Dot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That-there's for his orthodonture  and his college. You soak his thumb  in iodine you might get by without  the orthodonture, but it won't knock  any off the college. Hi sits stoically. Dot is looking offscreen:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Reilly, take that diaper off your  head and put it back on your  sister!... Anyway, you probably got  the life insurance all squared away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You done that yet honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta do that, Hi! Ed here's got  her hands full with that little angel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would Ed and the angel do if a  truck came along and splattered your  brains all over the interstate? Where  would you be then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah honey, what if you get run over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or you got carried off by a twister?

dialogues.speaker: LAKESIDE PATH
dialogues.text: We are tracking on Hi and Glen as they walk side by side. Glen is sopping wet, wearing only swimming suit and wing- tipped shoes. His body is ghostly pale except for a V-are at his neck and his arms below the short-sleeve line, whi are a bright angry red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear about the person of the Polish  persuasion he walks into a bar holdin'  a pile of shit in his hands, says  "Look what I almost stepped in." Glen bursts out laughing; Hi walks on in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yeah, that's funny all right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya damn right it's funny! Shit man,  what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno... maybe it's wife, kids,  family life... I mean are you, uh,  satisfied Glen?  Don't y'ever feel  suffocated? Like, like there's  somethin' big pressin' down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solemnly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eeeeeyep... I do know the feelin'. Hi shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunno-
